Message.Title: is AMZN overvalued ?
Message.Msg: Not if you compare its price to sales ratio with other companies . AMZN PS ratio is only 2.34 compared to railroad companies such as Kansas City southern which has a PS ratio of 5.86 .or UNP at 3.25. Or how about Netflix at 4.49 ? All that AMZN has to do is increase its profit margins from a ridiculously low 0.19% and its profit could rocket higher . Disclosure I have no AMZN holding and no short position

Topic.Title: is AMZN overvalued ?

Message.Msg: Analysts keep upgrading AMZN regardless its PE. OK let 's forget about PE now. Just talk about the its operating cash flow. It has around $5B positive cash flow in the last 12 months. Assume it does not do any investment, so, the max income is $5B for whole year, which is still not enough to support $160B market cap company. There are many companies with this market cap can make more than $10B profit even after spending on billions in investment.

Message.Title: Nemesis how much money will AMZN make from groceries
Message.Msg: What should be a good estimate of margin, like 20%? Or as long as revenues go up regardless of the expenses it is all good in the long run? From an article today: "Amazon can’t produce this kind of cost differential in groceries, because grocery stores rely on free labor — yours — to do all the laborious bits of fulfilling orders. You wander around the store with your cart, pile it all in, compare the prices of various brands of frozen chicken tenders, and these days, you may even be your own checkout girl. Then you drive it home to your house, unload the car and put the groceries in the kitchen. In order to deliver your groceries, Amazon has to pay someone at least $10 an hour to do all that work for you.

Topic.Title: Nemesis how much money will AMZN make from groceries

Message.Msg: Book stores rely on free labor, too. Long-term over-all margins have been estimated to be in the high single digits eventually. For groceries you might try a proxy around say what Walmart or Safeway makes on that category. I'm sure Walmart's margins are much higher for some lines (electronics) than for perishables in the grocery lines. I'm also sure that for some items Walmart has negative margins (loss leaders). People will order other stuff along with groceries the same way they currently buy general merchandise on the same shopping trip at a Walmart or Target. You shorts sound really clueless on the most basic facts of retailing.

Topic.Title: is AMZN overvalued ?

Message.Msg: AMZN is definitely a greater-fool play. The fundamentals don't seem to matter much. Amazon increases its sales by starting new businesses. Any business can do that. You can do that. In fact, you can do it until you are so deep in debt the bubble bursts. Amazon's bottom line, its net worth (net tangible assets) hasn't changed for years, so the price per book just keeps growing. Finally, what is the point of doing so much business if you never make a profit? Companies that don't make profits go down eventually.

Topic.Title: Nemesis how much money will AMZN make from groceries

Topic.Title: Nemesis how much money will AMZN make from groceries

Message.Msg: what's interesting about the AMZN model right now is that for most companies, incremental sales dollars have a higher value, because they drop part of them to the bottom line. In AMZN's case, the sales dollars are TAKING dollars from the bottom line , yet the market is valuing them more than they would for other companies in the market. A very interesting set of cirumstances right now. So much for what 'scale' would do for AMZN up to now, though the market right now seems "wowed" by it all. This is part of the Einhorn "riddle" of AMZN he made of couple of years ago. I guess all these "Kiva" type investments are gonna kick in at some point but they sure havn't yet.

Topic.Title: Nasdaq 4000 reality

Message.Msg: The predatory trading games have led to the greatest misallocation of capital ever. The Fed has absolutely amplified the problems, but the underlying issue is the structure of the market itself. It is one giant trading/skimming operation. There is very little true investment taking place, which means very little value created... just glorified theft. The ONLY was we get out of this mess is for the capital to leave the trading scams and to get deployed into real investment in productive assets. Else, capital is tied up in zero sum games...
